Name: Quinclorac
Description: Quinclorac is a quinolinemonocarboxylic acid that is quinoline-8-carboxylic acid in which the hydrogens at positions 3 and 7 have been replaced by chlorines. It is used (particularly as its dimethylamine salt, known as quinclorac-dimethylammonium) as a (rather persistent) herbicide for the post-emergence control of weeds in rice, grass and turf. It is not approved for use within the European Union. It has a role as a herbicide, an agrochemical and a synthetic auxin. It is a quinolinemonocarboxylic acid, an organochlorine compound and a monocarboxylic acid. It is a conjugate acid of a quinclorac(1-).

plant_translocations.content: The study evaluated the movement of 14C-labeled quinclorac within barnyardgrass biotypes, focusing on absorption and translocation in resistant (R-BYG) and susceptible (S-BYG) plants. Interestingly, while both biotypes absorbed quinclorac similarly, the distribution within the plants differed significantly. S-BYG retained more 14C in the treated leaf compared to R-BYG, indicating different translocation patterns. R-BYG showed higher acropetal translocation, moving 14C more into leaves above the treated leaf than S-BYG, possibly due to reduced herbicide sequestration or increased binding affinity within the treated leaf. Conversely, S-BYG exhibited higher retention in the treated leaf and slower translocation, suggesting potential herbicide immobilization. Notably, minimal 14C was detected in roots, but R-BYG exuded more quinclorac into the growth media, possibly due to herbicide-induced damage or metabolic differences. These variations in translocation might not explain the quinclorac resistance fully, necessitating further research to clarify if it involves metabolism or altered binding proteins affecting herbicide movement within the plants.
plant_translocations.reference: Lovelace, M. L., Talbert, R. E., Hoagland, R. E., & Scherder, E. F. (2007). Quinclorac Absorption and Translocation Characteristics in Quinclorac- and Propanil-resistant and -susceptible Barnyardgrass (Echinochloa Crus-galli) Biotypes. Weed Technology, 21(3), 683–687. doi:10.1614/wt-06-060.1

method.Test Plant: Barnyardgrass (suspected of quinclorac and propanil resistance)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Plants were placed in a growth chamber (30/20 C; 16-h days; photosynthetic photon flux density of 500 umol m**-2 s*01 1 ;95 +- 5% relative humidity).
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Four-leaf plants were treated with four 1-ml droplets of 14C-quinclorac formulated in combination with the spray solution (Facet 75 DFand surfactant) to give 416.67 Bq/ml, and a final herbicide concentration of 13.3 mM.
method.Other Information: Tests were conducted twice, with each test conducted as a randomized complete block with four replications.

plant_translocations.content: Studies were initiated to evaluate absorption, translocation, and distribution of 14C-quinclorac in propanil- and quinclorac-resistant (R-BYG) and -susceptible (S-BYG) barnyardgrass. No differential absorption of 14C-quinclorac was observed between R-BYG and S-BYG, but more 14C remained in the treated leaf of S-BYG (57% of total absorbed) compared with the R-BYG leaf (34% of total absorbed) at 72 hours after treatment (HAT). After 12 HAT, 20 and 15% of the amount absorbed had been translocated basipetally by R-BYG and S-BYG, respectively. At 72 HAT, 27 and 17% of the total absorbed 14C had been translocated acropetally by R-BYG and S-BYG, respectively. The levels of 14C above the treated leaf continued to increase throughout the duration of the experiment in R-BYG while levels of 14C above the treated leaf in S-BYG remained relatively constant. Seven percent more of the total absorbed 14C was exuded from roots of R-BYG than S-BYG at 72 HAT. Although differential translocation was observed between R-BYG and S-BYG, it is unclear whether this difference is a cause of quinclorac resistance or an effect of some other physiological process. Further research is needed to determine if differential translocation is due to metabolism or other physiological factors
plant_translocations.reference: Lovelace, M.L.; Talbert, R.E.; Hoagland, R.E.; Scherder, E.F.  (2007). Quinclorac Absorption and Translocation Characteristics in Quinclorac- and Propanil-resistant and -susceptible Barnyardgrass (Echinochloa Crus-galli) Biotypes. Weed Technology, 21(3), 683–687.doi:10.1614/WT-06-060.1

method.Test Plant: Barnyardgrass population suspected of quinclorac and propanil resistance
method.Plant Grown Condition: Seeds from the barnyardgrass population were collected from a rice field in Craighead County, Arkansas in 1999. The plants were grown to maturity for seed increase. Seeds from a susceptible barnyardgrass population maintained at the University of Arkansas were also used.
method.Chemical Preparation: Plants were treated with standard registered rates of quinclorac (420 g ai/ha) plus nonionic surfactant (0.25% v/v), propanil (4.48 kg ai/ha), or a combination of quinclorac plus propanil (no surfactant) at these respective rates. Quinclorac treatments were applied to plants at the four-leaf growth stage.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Plants were treated with a broadcast application of quinclorac (Facet 75 DF) at 0.21 kg ai/ha and nonionic surfactant at 0.25% v/v using a track sprayer in an enclosed spray chamber calibrated to deliver 187 L/ha of spray solution. Four-leaf plants were treated with four 1-ml droplets of 14C-quinclorac formulated in combination with the spray solution (Facet 75 DF and surfactant) to give 416.67 Bq/ml, and a final herbicide concentration of 13.3 mM. The adaxial surface of the third leaf was treated with four 1-ml droplets of the spotting solution using a digital microsyringe.
method.Other Information: Tests were conducted twice, with each test conducted as a randomized complete block with four replications, and treatments were arranged as a two-factor factorial (biotype by time of harvest).

plant_translocations.content: Absorption, translocation, and metabolism studies using 14C-quinclorac were conducted with quinclorac-sensitive Digitaria sanguinalis and quinclorac-tolerant Eleusine indica at the one- to two-tiller growth stage cultured under hydroponic conditions. After an 80-h exposure time, both species had absorbed nearly equal amounts of 14C-quinclorac (27 and 22% for D. sanguinalis and E. indica, respectively). Over the exposure period, the absorption curve for D. sanguinalis was curvilinear, with the maximum absorption occurring approximately 48 h after exposure. The response curve for E. indica was linear across the exposure period. Results from the translocation studies showed that 95% of the absorbed 14C-quinclorac remained in the treated leaf for D. sanguinalis after 80 h. However, only 58% of the absorbed 14C remained in the treated leaf of E. indica. Most of the 14C translocated out of the leaves moved to the tiller, the crown, and new leaf tissue. There was no appreciable exudation of 14C-quinclorac by either species during the absorption period. Results of the metabolism studies showed that neither the susceptible species (D. sanguinalis) nor the tolerant species (E. indica) metabolized the parent quinclorac herbicide. Spray retention studies showed that E. indica (tolerant) retained more applied quinclorac than D. sanguinalis (sensitive). Overall results suggested that a large difference in tolerance of the two species to quinclorac involves mechanisms other than absorption, metabolism, or spray retention
plant_translocations.reference: Zawierucha, J. E., & Penner, D. (2000). Absorption, translocation, metabolism, and spray retention of quinclorac inDigitaria sanguinalisandEleusine indica. Weed Science, 48(3), 296–301. doi:10.1614/0043-1745(2000)048[0296:atmasr]2.0.co;2

method.Test Plant: Digitaria sanguinalis (crabgrass) and Echinochloa colona (jungle rice)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Seeds were seeded into pure sand and covered with a 1-cm layer of Metro Mix 360 greenhouse potting soil in 946-ml plastic pots. The pots received an application of OSMOCOTE fertilizer (10-10-10) at planting and were maintained with daily overhead irrigation. Greenhouse conditions were maintained at approximate day/night temperatures of 30/20°C with a 16-h photoperiod consisting of natural light supplemented with metal halide light at 600 µmol m^-2 s^-1 photosynthetic photon flux (PPF).
method.Chemical Preparation: Plants were oversprayed with non-labeled, formulated quinclorac at a rate of 0.56 kg ai ha^-1 with Merge spray adjuvant at 1% (v/v). The radiolabeled spotting solution contained [3^14C]-labeled quinclorac with a specific activity of 1.5 x 10^3 kBq mg^-1, formulated, non-labeled quinclorac, and Merge spray adjuvant at 1% (v/v). Each plant was spotted on the adaxial leaf surface with two 1-µL droplets containing 500 Bq each of radioactivity (1,000 Bq total per leaf).
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Plants were oversprayed with non-labeled, formulated quinclorac at a rate of 0.56 kg ai ha^-1 with Merge spray adjuvant at 1% (v/v). Each plant was spotted on the adaxial leaf surface with two 1-µL droplets containing 500 Bq each of radioactivity (1,000 Bq total per leaf).
method.Other Information: Tests were conducted twice, with each test conducted as a randomized complete block with four replications. Plants were harvested at 0, 2, 4, 8, 24, 48, and 80 hours after treatment.

plant_translocations.content: Research was conducted to deternine the role of uptake, distribution, and metabolism of quinclorac in differential sensitivity of southern crabgrass and Kentucky bluegrass. At 0.5 h, quinclorac uptake was 85% in southern crabgrass and 66% in bluegrass. Uptake and distribution differed between species. By 128 h, Kentucky bluegrass had uniformly distributed quinclorac and exuded 17% into the nutrient solution. Metabolism of quinclorac was limited to less than 3.6% of the applied 14C in the two species, at 128 h. Selectivity of quinclorac may be influenced by differences in uptake, distribution, and exudation by the roots but not by metabolism.
plant_translocations.reference: Chism, W. J., Bingham, S. W., & Shaver, R. L. (1991). Uptake, translocation, and metabolism of quinclorac in two grass species. Weed Technology, 5(4), 771-775.

method.Test Plant: Southern crabgrass (Digitaria ciliaris) and Kentucky bluegrass (Poa pratensis)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Southern crabgrass seeds were germinated in vermiculite in the greenhouse and transferred at the one-true leaf stage to 230-ml pots containing Appling fine sandy loam soil (pH 6.7 and 1.9% organic matter). Kentucky bluegrass plants with five to six leaves, from an established field planting (1.5 yr old), were transferred directly into modified nutrient solution. Plants were grown to four true leaves for Southern crabgrass and five to six leaves for Kentucky bluegrass, with average day/night temperatures in the greenhouse at 35/25°C, noon ambient light levels averaging 650 µmol m^-2 s^-1, and a natural photoperiod of 14 h.
method.Chemical Preparation: Plants were treated by spotting a 2-cm^2 area using a single 1-µL droplet of methanol containing 250 Bq of uniformly ring-labeled 14C-quinclorac (specific activity 1500 kBq mg^-1) plus 0.06% surfactant (v/v) on the youngest fully expanded leaf of each plant.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Plants were treated by spotting a 2-cm^2 area using a single 1-µL droplet of methanol containing 250 Bq of uniformly ring-labeled 14C-quinclorac (specific activity 1500 kBq mg^-1) plus 0.06% surfactant (v/v) on the youngest fully expanded leaf of each plant.
method.Other Information: Each experiment was performed twice as a completely randomized design with four replications.
